questions.question: Which of the following are valid types of maintenance activities in the SDLC maintenance phase?
questions.option_a: A. Corrective Maintenance - fixing bugs found after deployment
questions.option_b: B. Adaptive Maintenance - updating software to work in new environments
questions.option_c: C. Perfective Maintenance - adding new features or enhancing performance
questions.option_d: D. Preventive Maintenance - refactoring code to prevent future issues
questions.explanation: Corrective, Adaptive, and Perfective maintenance are classic SDLC maintenance categories.

questions.question: In UML State Machine Diagrams, which statements correctly describe transitions and their elements?
questions.option_a: A. A transition must have a source state and a target state
questions.option_b: B. Self-transitions cause the state to be exited and re-entered, executing exit and entry actions
questions.option_c: C. Guard conditions on transitions are mandatory elements
questions.option_d: D. A trigger is the event that causes the transition to occur
questions.explanation: Transitions have source/target, optional guards, and triggers that cause transitions.

questions.question: According to the Gang of Four design patterns classification, which patterns belong to the Creational category?
questions.option_a: A. Singleton Pattern
questions.option_b: B. Observer Pattern
questions.option_c: C. Factory Pattern
questions.option_d: D. Decorator Pattern
questions.explanation: Singleton and Factory are creational; Observer and Decorator belong to other pattern types.

questions.question: In Scrum methodology, which activities are part of the Sprint cycle?
questions.option_a: A. Sprint Planning - defining sprint goals and selecting backlog items
questions.option_b: B. Daily Scrum - 15-minute stand-up to discuss progress and obstacles
questions.option_c: C. Sprint Review - demonstrating completed work to stakeholders
questions.option_d: D. Sprint Retrospective - reflecting on process improvements
questions.explanation: Core Scrum events include planning, daily scrum, review, and retrospective.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid stereotypes for objects in UML Sequence Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Boundary Objects - objects at the system boundary that actors interact with
questions.option_b: B. Control Objects - objects that control and coordinate other objects
questions.option_c: C. Entity Objects - objects representing information and behavior in the application domain
questions.option_d: D. Service Objects - objects exposing web services
questions.explanation: Boundary, Control, and Entity are standard UML stereotypes used in analysis and design.

questions.question: In software testing using Boundary Value Analysis, which test values should be selected for an input field accepting numbers from 10 to 100?
questions.option_a: A. 9 (just below lower boundary)
questions.option_b: B. 10 (lower boundary)
questions.option_c: C. 55 (middle value)
questions.option_d: D. 100 (upper boundary)
questions.explanation: Boundary Value Analysis includes values just below and above the boundaries.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized drawbacks of the Waterfall Model?
questions.option_a: A. No working software is produced until late in the cycle
questions.option_b: B. Changes are difficult and costly once a phase is completed
questions.option_c: C. Testing occurs late, making early defect detection difficult
questions.option_d: D. Customer sees the product only after full development
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model’s main drawbacks are rigidity and late validation.

questions.question: In Use Case Diagrams, which relationships are correctly matched with their descriptions?
questions.option_a: A. Association - indicates an actor participates in a use case
questions.option_b: B. Include - base use case explicitly incorporates another use case's behavior
questions.option_c: C. Extend - adds optional behavior at extension points
questions.option_d: D. Generalization - child inherits behavior from parent
questions.explanation: Association, Include, Extend, and Generalization are valid use case relationships.

questions.question: Which statements correctly describe characteristics of the Observer Design Pattern?
questions.option_a: A. It defines a one-to-many dependency between objects
questions.option_b: B. When the subject changes state, all observers are notified
questions.option_c: C. Observers can subscribe and unsubscribe at runtime
questions.option_d: D. The subject maintains a list of registered observers
questions.explanation: Observer defines one-to-many relationships, enabling updates to observers automatically.

questions.question: In Activity Diagrams, which statements about control flow elements are accurate?
questions.option_a: A. A fork creates multiple concurrent flows from one
questions.option_b: B. A join synchronizes multiple flows back into one
questions.option_c: C. Decision nodes require guard conditions for each branch
questions.option_d: D. Merge nodes combine flows from decision branches
questions.explanation: Forks, joins, and decisions structure control flow in activity diagrams.

questions.question: In the requirements gathering phase, which technique involves observing users performing their daily work?
questions.option_a: A. Interviews
questions.option_b: B. Questionnaires
questions.option_c: C. Document Analysis
questions.option_d: D. Observations
questions.explanation: Observation reveals user challenges by studying real-world task performance.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a feasibility study before starting a project?
questions.option_a: A. To write detailed technical specifications
questions.option_b: B. To determine if the project should proceed based on technical, economic, and legal factors
questions.option_c: C. To create the project schedule
questions.option_d: D. To recruit the development team
questions.explanation: Feasibility studies assess whether the project is viable in all critical aspects.

questions.question: In the V-Model, what testing corresponds to the Requirements phase?
questions.option_a: A. Unit Testing
questions.option_b: B. Integration Testing
questions.option_c: C. System Testing
questions.option_d: D. Acceptance Testing
questions.explanation: Acceptance testing verifies requirements from the customer’s perspective.

questions.question: What distinguishes the Iterative Waterfall Model from the traditional one?
questions.option_a: A. It eliminates the testing phase
questions.option_b: B. It allows feedback and revisions between phases
questions.option_c: C. It uses sprints instead of phases
questions.option_d: D. It completes all phases simultaneously
questions.explanation: Iterative Waterfall permits backward movement between phases for refinement.

questions.question: In Agile User Stories, what does the 'So that' clause represent?
questions.option_a: A. The user role requesting the feature
questions.option_b: B. The specific action or goal
questions.option_c: C. The benefit or value delivered to the user
questions.option_d: D. The acceptance criteria for the story
questions.explanation: The 'So that' clause expresses the business value or user benefit.

questions.question: What is the main difference between functional and non-functional requirements?
questions.option_a: A. Functional defines what the system does; non-functional defines how it performs
questions.option_b: B. Functional are always more important
questions.option_c: C. Non-functional only deals with interface design
questions.option_d: D. Functional cannot be tested
questions.explanation: Functional describes system behavior; non-functional covers performance and constraints.

questions.question: In UML Sequence Diagrams, what does the REF fragment represent?
questions.option_a: A. A loop fragment
questions.option_b: B. A conditional alternative flow
questions.option_c: C. A reference to another diagram to manage complexity
questions.option_d: D. A parallel execution fragment
questions.explanation: REF fragments reference other interactions for modular and simpler diagrams.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the guard condition in a LOOP fragment of a Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. To define when the loop should terminate
questions.option_b: B. To specify involved actors
questions.option_c: C. To prevent unauthorized access
questions.option_d: D. To set execution priority
questions.explanation: Guard conditions define loop continuation or termination criteria.

questions.question: In State Machine Diagrams, what symbol represents the initial state?
questions.option_a: A. A circle with a dot inside
questions.option_b: B. A filled black circle
questions.option_c: C. A rounded rectangle
questions.option_d: D. A diamond shape
questions.explanation: The filled black circle marks the initial state in UML state diagrams.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a 'miracle state' in State Machine Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. A state with outgoing transitions but none incoming
questions.option_b: B. A state with complex internal behavior
questions.option_c: C. A state that resolves errors automatically
questions.option_d: D. A state that processes data extremely fast
questions.explanation: A miracle state is unreachable except from start and has only outgoing transitions.
